verses.text: No evil will seize anyone who fears the Lord, but in trials He will deliver them again and again.
verses.comment: As throughout Wisdom literature, the fear of the Lord safeguards a person from real harm, even when troubles arise. Echoes with the promise of God's protection for those loyal to Him.

verses.text: The wise person will not hate the law, but those pretending to keep it are like a ship caught in a storm.
verses.comment: True wisdom loves divine instruction; hypocrisy leads to instability. Note the contrast between delighting in the law and its rejection.

verses.text: A sensible person trusts in the law, and the law is as trustworthy as a divine oracle.
verses.comment: God's law is emphasized as an unfailing guide, reinforcing the foundation of revelation and tradition.

verses.text: Prepare your words, and you will be listened to; compose your answer, and you will be heard.
verses.comment: The wise person plans speech, linking wisdom to self-control and intentional communication.

verses.text: The thoughts of a fool are like wagon wheels spinning, and his mind is like a cart rolling down a road.
verses.comment: Foolishness causes restless instability, showing the need for discipline and the wisdom found in Christ who brings inner peace.

verses.text: Reasoning with a fool is like trying to carry a heavy load—ridiculous effort leads to nothing.
verses.comment: Engaging fruitlessly with those lacking wisdom is discouraged, highlighting practical discernment for believers.

verses.text: Why is one day greater than another, when each day of the light in the year is given by the Most High?
verses.comment: Implied here is the idea of sacred times—God assigning special meaning to particular days, foreshadowing the Christian liturgical year.

verses.text: The Lord set them apart, appointing different days, some as holy and others as ordinary.
verses.comment: Here is an anticipation of holy days and feasts preserved in sacred tradition. God establishes sacred times for worship.

verses.text: All people are from dust, and out of the earth Adam was formed.
verses.comment: Human equality at creation is affirmed, but the text prepares for the distinction of roles within sacred history.

verses.text: Yet, in God's power, people are made different: some He blesses and exalts, others He makes holy, and some He appoints for Himself.
verses.comment: Divine election in the Old Testament foreshadows the calling and sanctification found in the Church.

verses.text: Some are set apart to be honored by God, others to humble themselves before Him.
verses.comment: God's providence orders distinctions among people for His holy purposes, encouraging humility and service.

verses.text: As clay is in the potter’s hands, so are all men in the hands of Him who made them, to give them as He decides.
verses.comment: Echoes teaching that God sovereignly shapes our lives. This image is later beautifully fulfilled in Christ's hands guiding His people.

verses.text: Good is opposed to evil, life to death, so the sinner is opposed to the godly.
verses.comment: Biblical dualities in creation point to a deeper spiritual reality found in the victory of Christ.

verses.text: Thus, look at all the works of the Most High; they come in pairs, each one the opposite of the other.
verses.comment: Balance in creation points toward the harmony that God brings through redemption.

verses.text: I woke up in the last days, and listened as I received understanding; I declare what I have heard.
verses.comment: "Last days" allusion hints at prophetic wisdom, looking forward to Christ who brings fullness of revelation.

verses.text: By the word of the Lord I gained knowledge, and I share it freely with you.
verses.comment: Reception of wisdom prepares the way for Christ, the Word incarnate, who shares divine truth with all.

verses.text: Work for yourselves, for not all instruction profited me; rather I gave myself wholly to wisdom.
verses.comment: Personal dedication to wisdom reflects perseverance in discipleship and pursuit of the fullness of truth.

verses.text: Listen to me, great ones and rulers of the congregation: hear me, leaders of the people.
verses.comment: Authority and hierarchy are addressed, echoing both Old Testament and early Church realities.

verses.text: Let neither gold nor silver sway you, nor brute strength decide your course.
verses.comment: Warns against materialism and favoritism, calling leaders to righteousness, which Christ later perfects.

verses.text: How can you say, 'I am powerful, I am above others?' Remember: the Lord made all, and His judgment is without partiality.
verses.comment: Divine impartiality affirms the need for humility before God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: Assign work to your servant; let him serve you as you serve the Lord.
verses.comment: Earthly practices of stewardship are sanctified when performed in view of obedience to the Lord.

verses.text: If you have a servant, treat him as a brother, for you need his services as you do your own life.
verses.comment: Foundation of Christian dignity for all, anticipating the fullness of charity in later teaching.

verses.text: If you mistreat him and he runs away, where will you look for him, and what will you say?
verses.comment: Ethics of relationship, grounded in mercy and justice, foundational for Christian social teaching.

verses.text: Wisdom is like a master over slaves; do not abandon your inheritance.
verses.comment: Warning to treasure one's spiritual inheritance, paralleling the value of maintaining faith and tradition.

verses.text: Work a servant hard, and he will seek rest. Let idle hands find labor, for laziness teaches much evil.
verses.comment: Idleness is warned against; virtue is cultivated through diligent labor, a principle in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: Put him to work, as befits his role: if he does not obey, place him in chains.
verses.comment: Discipline, within justice, is advocated. The principle is later transformed by Christ into guidance grounded in love and mercy.

verses.text: But do not overburden anyone; act justly with him and you will find rest in your own soul.
verses.comment: Justice and mercy are balanced, reflecting Christ’s own example in dealing with all people.

verses.text: If a servant is disobedient, correct him. If he understands, do not punish unnecessarily.
verses.comment: Discipline is always for restoration; kindness and justice are the marks of true authority.

verses.text: Food and clothing are what a servant deserves, but do not let your heart be bitter toward him.
verses.comment: Love and provision for those in service is prioritized, anticipating the commandment of charity.

verses.text: If you have a servant, treat him well, and you will have joy; do not despise a wise servant—he will be more valuable than your own family.
verses.comment: Value is found in virtue, not status. This anticipates the New Testament’s teaching of the dignity of all in Christ.

verses.text: Treat him as your equal, for you need him just as much as he needs you.
verses.comment: Christian unity breaks down barriers, bringing everyone together through divine love.

verses.text: If you mistreat him and he escapes, where will you go to look for him, and with what face will you seek him?
verses.comment: Failure in charity brings regret; the passage calls for justice and loving stewardship.

verses.text: Wisdom is found in those who serve rightly: so strive for knowledge, and God will grant you favor.
verses.comment: Conclusion exhorts pursuit of wisdom with humility, which God rewards. Servanthood is reinterpreted as a spiritual vocation, a prelude to Christian life of grace.
